titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV:45.— Walk round Capitol Square. Sun rose 6:50.

Coll. Stone is editor of a Newspaper at New-York, and came as a visitor with Mr Gales of the National Intelligencer. Governor Kent was also a visitor, and dined with us— Commodore Barron came with Mr Lee— He told me that the Lieutenant Barron who lost his life by the bursting of a gun, on board the Boston Frigate in March 1778. was his uncle— He said Captain Tucker had told him Lieutenant Barron died, because, after the amputation of his leg, the motion of swinging in his Cot, brought on a fatal fever and he said this had induced him to invent a machine to regulate the movement of a Cot on board ship, for invalids— Mr Brent, brought a Letter from MaitlandKennedy and Maitland, of New-York to Mr Laird of Georgetown, enquiring for answer to certain applications some days since addressed to me soliciting for James L Kennedy an appointment as Consul at the Port of Mazatlan, in the Province of Sinaloa; California; under the Government of Mexico— I found the papers after some search, and desired Mr Brent to make out and forward immediately a Commission to Mr Kennedy— Mr Hough came to recommend his brother for an appointment as Indian Agent, in the place of Major O’Fallon, who he says has resigned, or intends to resign. I advised him to apply to the Department of War— Mr Clay spoke of the Instructions to be given to Mr Gallatin; and of the notice to be taken of G. Canning’s Note upon the interdiction by Great Britain, of our trade with her West-India Colonies. I said that as soon as Governor Barbour and Mr Rush would be able to attend, I should wish a consultation with the members of the Administration, to determine what course it would be proper to take upon this new term of British policy—in which revenge appears to be the predominant ingredient— I observed to Mr Clay that as this note, not only refused to negotiate upon the subject, but declared a determination to adhere to the interdiction, even if the United States would now agree to remove all discriminating duties, there was no alternative left us, but resistance or submission— That my own sentiment was in favour of resistance; but that the choice must be left to Congress where it would occasion violent debate; and where it was to be expected the opposition would take side against us. It would be necessary to communicate to Congress all the correspondence relating to this Colonial trade for some years back, and I wished him to direct the making of the copies at the Department of State, immediately; including the part of the Instructions to Mr Gallatin relating to this subject— The Sun rose clear, but the day was stormy— I planted in a corner of the Garden six Chesnuts from the Trees of which the nuts were planted by President Washington and Judge Peters in the garden of the latter near Philadelphia— Twelve Walnuts, from the Shellbark tree at Quincy, the nut of which was planted by me 8. October 1804. and twenty-four small chesnuts, which I brought from Mr Boylston’s at Princeton. Mrs Adams continues unwell; confined to her chamber— I wrote in the Evening; continuing my draft of a Message to Congress.
2. VI— Fog— Walk round Capitol Square.

Mrs Wilson was a petitioner for charity— Mr Wertz came again to enquire of his prospects for obtaining his Commission as a Justice of Peace— I told him I had received from Mr Coyle, the person who had principally objected to his appointment a Letter bearing testimony to the correctness of Wertz’s conduct, since the time when he was appointed, but which I could not consider as withdrawing his objections to the appointment— But I desired him to call again in the course of the next week; and told him I would in the meantime make further enquiries; and if the result of them should
prove satisfactory, would do for him what might be in my power— The Deportment of the man under his trials has rather prepossessed me in his favour. Mr Clay called to introduce Mr Cooley, appointed Chargé d’Affaires to Peru, and who is on the search for an opportunity of conveyance to his post. The Postmaster General sent me some days since a Letter from a man living in the neighbourhood of West Point, complaining of a series of grievances, in sundry alledged arbitrary acts, of Coll. Thayer, Superintendent of the Military Academy—especially in forbidding him to go to the Post-Office on the Point— He represents Thayer’s treatment of him as altogether arbitrary and oppressive— I advised Mr M’lean unofficially to send a copy of this Letter to Coll. Thayer, apprizing him that the course was taken in preference to a direct official call through the Department of War, and said I had no doubt Thayer’s answer would present the subject in a light altogether different— He said Thayer and the Officers at West-Point had raised some pretension of appointing the Postmaster there themselves, which was quite inadmissible; and that Thayer was now under a prosecution for false imprisonment, at the suit of this man whom he had prohibited from coming to the Point, and whose name is Cole— He also shewed me, a new Letter from J. Binns to him; repeating his complaints against R. Bache, Postmaster at Philadelphia, for disgraceful and outrageously indecent conduct at Cape May, and also for the delay of a Letter, written by him to Mr. Markley in May, and not received till August. Mr M’lean said there should be a strict enquiry into the latter charge:—but the other was for private misbehaviour, over which it would be difficult to exercise official controul— I asked Mr M’Lean to prepare a statement of the affairs and Condition of the Post-Office, Department, to be used in the annual Message to Congress; which he promised— Coll. Baldwin of New-Haven, and Coll. Bomford came together— Mrs Adams is yet so ill that she this day by the advice of Dr Huntt, resorted to cupping, and to the use of leaches; both without success— Her situation gives me great anxiety— Evening employed in writing. symbols
3. V:30. Round Capitol Square— Sun rose in cloud— Clear above.

Mr Smith came to enquire again concerning the devise to him by my father; and the amount of his own debt to me. I shewed him his two Notes; one of 27. April 1814. for $1088:03. and the other of 10. July 1818. for $200. He said there were 200 dollars more, which I had lent him at two several times, 100 dollars each, but for which he had not given Notes— I said that not possessing evidence of those debts I had not claimed them— He said they were equally due, and he would give me an order upon the Executors for the full amount including them— But he wished the Executors then to pay the balance of the devise to his order, as he wished to have the merit of paying his own debts—by his own Acts and Will; and without the interference of others, assuming the Province of the Law— I told him that I had directed the attachment to be made, with a view to the payment first of his debt to me, and to the other members of his family if they should wish to have the benefit of the attachment, particularly Mr De Wint and Mr Frye; and then to prevail upon him to make provision, for debts due to R. Forrest, to Mr H. de Neuville, and to the Estate of the late Mr William Gray, or to F. C. Gray, or to both, debts which I believed existed and ought to be paid but the amount of which I did not know— That my object was to prevent other creditors with less meritorious debts from acquiring a preference for the payment of them by a mere priority of attachment, and that with regards to the debt due to me, it was not my intention to derive personally the benefit of one dollar for the payment of it— He said that he had been twice under the necessity of
declaring his inability to pay his debts, and that it had been his determination to pay them, if he ever should be able— That he should therefore now be obliged to give equally public notice to all his Creditors, that there was this sum deposited in the Bank at Boston, and leave it thus to be disposed of— I said I had no objection to his taking this course— I had no personal interest in the distribution, and was entirely willing that it should be disposed of as the Law should direct. He then said this would operate very hard upon him— That he supposed Mr De Wint and Mr Frye would be willing to wait for the payment of the debts due to them, and he was in immediate want of five hundred dollars to provide for the current expenses of his family and enable him to get along without continually anticipating his Salary. I said that if Mr De Wint, and Mr Frye would say or write to me that they were willing the attachment should be removed so far as concerned their claims, it should immediately be so— He left me, after making a minute of an alteration I had suggested as proper in the Order upon the Executors, for the payment of his debt to me— Commodore Warrington recently arrived from Norfolk called for a visit— Mr Weightman the Mayor of the City came with two Resolutions of the Boards of Aldermen and Common Council, one passed 7. July last, respecting the appointment of a City Surveyor; and the other of 31. October, requesting the appointment of Engineer Officers for the graduation of the City according to the original plan of 1791. Mr Weightman expressed the wish that General Bernard might be appointed— I spoke to Foy about laying off a small piece of ground within the yard walls of the House, for planting nuts and acorns, and other seeds of Forest Trees, and asked him also to select two or three spots where I could plant some of the Spanish Chesnuts from judge Peters’s garden, and where if they should come up, the trees may remain without being transplanted— I would make a Nursery here, where the experiment might be tried of raising forest trees, foreign and domestic, from the seed, nut or acorn— I rode out with my Son John, and gathered some acorns in the Woods—chiefly from Black Oaks— We found but few, the Season being about a month too far advanced— John and Charles dined at Mr Clay’s.
4. IV. Round Capitol Square— Sun rose half beclouded; behind the Capitol Dome.

Mr Southard came to converse with me, upon various subjects of current business in the Department of the Navy, such as the appointment of two Lieutenants in the Marine Corps, a Purser, for a Schooner now bound to sea, and two or three Midshipmen— He afterwards sent me a Commission, which I signed, of 2d Lieutenant of Marines for Thomas Lee, grandson to a former Governor of Maryland, recommended among others by Charles Carroll of Carrollton, the last surviving Signer of the Declaration of Independence— He had several Candidates for the appointment of Purser, between whom he was somewhat embarrassed to make a Selection. Strong suspicions of improper conduct having lately arisen, against the person, whom he would otherwise have preferred: Suspicions of his having himself written an anonymous Letter which he shewed as having been received by him. Mr Southard said he was desirous of having a purser, even in the smallest vessel; the duties of that office being otherwise necessarily performed by the Captain, which placed him in a double relation to the men, detrimental to discipline— He said further that there were several applications for Midshipman’s Warrants in behalf of Cadets, discharged from West-Point: among which was one for a youth named Forsyth, a native of North-Carolina, son of an Officer who had been killed in the public Service, and now in the process of education at the charge of the State— He was last year reported for dismission, but retained at the earnest interposition of the delegation from the State. He must now be dismissed, for incapacity, but with testimonials altogether favourable to his character, temper and conduct.
The Governor of North-Carolina, and General Daniels now here are urgently soliciting for him a Midshipman’s warrant— I said it sometimes happened that a youth incapable of making much proficiency in study, was yet well suited to the business of active life and particularly to that of a Seaman— As there was positive evidence of this young man’s good conduct, I would give him another chance of making himself useful, and try him as a Midshipman— But the Warrant should not be granted to other dismissed Cadets, of whose conduct there was no favourable report; as it would be degrading the whole corps of midshipmen, to turnover to them all the refuse of West-Point— Mr Southard said he was examining the proceedings of the Court-Martial in the case of Lieutenant Constantine Smith, and thought he should be ready with his opinion next Monday. Mr Reynolds is a man who has been lecturing about the Country, in support of Captain John Cleves Symmes’s theory that the Earth is a hollow Sphere, open at the Poles— His Lectures are said to have been well attended, and much approved as exhibitions of genius and of Science— But the Theory itself has been so much ridiculed, and is in truth so visionary, that Reynolds has now varied his purpose to the proposition of fitting out a voyage of circumnavigation to the Southern Ocean— He has obtained numerous signatures in Baltimore to a Memorial to Congress for this object, which he says will otherwise be very powerfully supported— It will however have no support in Congress. That day will come, but not yet nor in my time. May it be my fortune, and my praise to accelerate its approach. Weightman a Clerk in the Branch Bank was here about an order of W. S. Smith upon my fathers Executors, in favour of R. Wallack, and endorsed by him, which Weightman had sent over to me— He told me that it was not a Bank Transaction, but that Wallack who was now at Alexandria, had given him the order to send to me— I told him I believed the order would be paid, and wished to see Mr Wallack concerning it of which Weightman said he would advise Wallack— The day was rainy and I spent much of it, in reading the proceedings of a Court Martial on the trial of Edwin R. Alberti 1st. Lieutenant in the 4th. Regiment of Artillery— John and Charles dined in the Baron de Mareuil’s, the French Minister, it being the Fête of the king of France— Mrs Adams is better but still keeps her chamber.
5. VI:45. Sunday— Sun rose beclouded— Gloomy day with little rain.

Heard Mr Little, from Psalm 119.133. “Order my steps in thy word: and let not any iniquity have dominion over me.” A desultory, and impressive moral discourse; setting forth by various illustrations the different modes by which iniquity may obtain dominion over us. Among his quotations from Scripture was that of the first seven verses of the fifth Chapter of Isaiah: the song of the vineyard that brought forth wild grapes— In this instance as in numberless others I was struck with the careless inattention of my own mind when reading the Bible— I have read the chapter of Isaiah containing the parable I dare say fifty times, and it was altogether familiar to my memory—but I had never perceived a fiftieth part of its beauty and sublimity— The closing verse of the parable especially which points the moral of the allegory speaks with irresistible energy. “For the vineyard of the Lord of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah his pleasant plant: and he looked for judgment but behold oppression; for righteousness, but behold a cry.” The parallel is pursued no further. He had said in the parable how the vineyard would be destroyed, and here after declaring what the vineyard was and what its fruits had been he leaves the conclusion of ruin and destruction to the imagination of the reader. This art of selecting ideas to be presented, and of leading the mind to that which is not expressed, is among the greatest secrets of composition—to make the suppressed thoughts like the Statues of Brutus and Cassius at the funeral of Juria most resplendent because they are not exhibited in the highest effort of skill.
After the Service, I called upon Governor Barbour who is yet confined to his chamber in an exceedingly debilitated state, but without fever— He says he has been five days without apparent change for better or worse. I had some conversation with him upon the British interdiction of our Colonial trade— Upon the Military Courts-Martial, upon whose sentences I am to decide, and upon the various objects in the War Department, to be touched upon in the annual message. He said all the Reports from the subordinate branches of the Department were in preparation, and would be very shortly brought to me. He spoke also of the board of officers assembled here to prepare a system of cavalry tactics and of Artillery Instruction for the Militia— Under a Resolution of Congress at their last Session; and said their Report was nearly ready— I next called upon Mr Rush whose Son died this day week, and who has not since left his house. I found him however composed, and he said he should go to the Treasury to-morrow. I mentioned also to him my wish for the Statements of Revenue and Expenditure necessary for the preparation of the annual Message; which he said he had ordered to be made out, and he thought would be ready to-morrow— We had also much conversation upon the British Colonial interdiction, and of the decided spirit of hostility to this Country indicated by it, and by the British Minister Canning’s note— He urged the necessity of exhibiting to the public all the previous correspondence upon this subject, which I told him I had determined should be done— He observed that he had seen the hand of Mr Tazewell in some comments of the Southern papers, charging the Government of the United States with failing to meet the liberal offers of Great-Britain upon this subject—which he said was a great misrepresentation— My next call was at Mr Frye’s, and I spoke to him of W. S. Smith’s debt to him— I told him of the order that Smith had given to Wallack, and suggested to him the expediency of his obtaining a similar order; for which he said he would apply. There was no afternoon service at Mr Baker’s nor at St. John’s Church; nor any in the Evening at Mr Little’s. The quarterly Sunday School Meeting was at Dr Lowrie’s, which I did not attend— Evening, wrote in my chamber.
6. V:45. Rain— no morning walk— Gloomy and Rainy day.

The whole day was absorbed by these visitors. Armistead is a young Man, who has been two or three years soliciting a Commission, as a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps, recommended by T. Newton, the Representative from Norfolk, and others— He has had some encouragement to expect success, and has been informed of the appointment of Saturday of T. Lee, who he says first applied last June— Richard Wallack informed me that the order endorsed by him in blank upon the Executors of my father, which was sent me on Saturday is in full for the Notes endorsed by R. Forrest, and for which he is liable. Mr Frye, brought me from W. S. Smith, an order upon the Executors of my father for the debt due to me, and an order in favour of Frye himself, which I thought it would be necessary to have altered— It includes a sum of 300 dollars, which Smith drew last December, a Bill for; upon his brother John, and which Frye endorsed; it was protested, and has been lying ever since last June at the Navy Department, Frye having until this day had no notice of the protest— Mr Frye took a receipt in full for my debt, together with Smith’s two Notes, to deliver them to him— Mr Southard being here witnessed my receipt— Mr Frye afterwards came back with a new order from Smith in his favour, but with a blank which I thought it necessary should be filled up— He took it again away for that purpose— Mr Southard had two large bundles of recommendations of various persons for the appointment of a purser and for that of a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps— We went over them all, an occupation of nearly three hours, and finally fixed upon a person named Etting for the purser, and upon Armistead for the Lieutenant— I also recommended that a Warrant of Midshipman should be sent to Penhallow— Mr Rush brought some papers from the Department of the Treasury, and two large bundles had already been sent me of applications and recommendations for appointments under that Department. There was another difficulty to remove
with regard to the delivery to Francis H. Nicoll of some of Edward Thompson’s Teas: the question was whether before delivery he should be required to pay the duties for them in cash; or only to give bonds. It was thought sufficient to take bonds— I gave Mr Rush a letter from Nicoll to me on this subject received yesterday, with two enclosures, which I desired him to send back to Nicoll— The papers from the Treasury to be used for the preparation of the Message are not yet quite ready— Mr Clay had sent me two private Letters from General P. B. Porter concerning the 7th. Article of the Ghent Treaty; and his observations on the proposition of Mr Vaughan’s Note—but there is yet an official Letter from Porter relating to it which I had not seen— Mr Clay in speaking of New-York, asked me if I had entire confidence in General Brown— I said yes— He appeared to think that Genl. Brown’s attachment to De Witt Clinton, might have some effect upon his conduct, and intimated that he had heard, Brown had been made the channel of a communication from General Jackson to Clinton, to secure his co-operation against the present Administration, on a conditional pledge in the Event of his own success, to make way for him at the end of four years. I told Mr Clay, I did not believe this— It was likely enough that such whispers from electioneering subalterns may have reached Mr Clinton’s ears— But no pledge upon which he could place any reliance could be given by Jackson himself, and none by his pretended supporters without displacing or abandoning Calhoun. The Condition of New-York is indeed precarious, and her policy, like that of Clinton, is cold, cautious and reserved— The next election yet depends upon the chapter Accidents, but behind that is a wise, unerring hand— Mr De grand came and dined, and spent the Evening till ten O’Clock with me—arguing profoundly to convince me of the expediency of appointing him Collector of the Port of Philadelphia, or a Director of the Bank of the United States— On veut etre Napoleon—sinon Prefet—ou bien gensdarme— He has come all the way from Philadelphia for this—and the Steam boat from Frenchtown in which he came, ran ashore in the Night on Pool’s island, where they stuck fourteen or fifteen hours, and were then taken out by the Steam-boat from Norfolk. Degrand says Captain Robertson, of the Steam-boat Constitution, which ran aground, has no energy— I had a rhumatic head-ache this Evening.— Lost my days walk.
7. V. Round the Capitol— Cloudy Morning— Clear eve.

Mr Pleasonton came, with a Letter of Recommendation for the appointment of a person as keeper of a Light house in Vermont, signed by the Governor, Lieutt. Governor, Speaker of the House of Representatives, Counsellors, and many others— He had already sent recommendations as numerous, strong and respectable for another person named Sawyer, and had himself recommended his appointment— I saw no reason for changing on account of the last received Letters and directed the appointment of Sawyer, and that the new candidate should be informed his application came too late— Mr Frye came with the order from W. S. Smith, the blank being filled—he had also the cancelled check, on the Bank, upon which Smith’s Note to him had arisen. He also brought me an order from Smith, for the balance of the 3000 dollars payable to him by the devise from my father, for which Frye said Smith expected I should send him the money— But as the debt due to Mr De Neuville was yet to be provided for, I did not receive the order but Mr Frye took it back. De grand called upon me twice, and re-urged his suit for an appointment as a Director of the Bank of the United States. I told him I had no doubt of his qualifications, but that to obtain the confirmation of the Senate, strong recommendations from persons of good standing, large Stockholders, and having an interest in the prosperity of the Bank would be indispensable— Mr Rush brought some of the Statements and papers relating to the condition of the Revenue, to be used in the preparation of the Message, but took them back again, not yet having them complete— He finds the prospects of the Revenue for the present, and the ensuing year, less flattering than he had expected yesterday. There will be a falling off in the receipts
of nearly three Millions, from those of the last year; those of the next year will be still more curtailed— Mr Rush spoke also of the necessity which there may shortly be for appointing a Collector at Philadelphia— Mr Steele is said not to have been at the office for more than a year— I have been earnestly and repeatedly urged to remove him, and have hitherto resisted— I suggested to Mr Rush the expediency of intimating to some friend of Steele’s, that if he is permanently disabled from attending upon his Office, he would do well to resign. We had some conversation upon the designation of a Successor, without coming to a determination— Mrs Smith and T. B. Johnson called on Mrs Adams this Evening— I spent part of it in writing.
8. VI:30— Sun rose 6:58. No morning walk.

I signed an order, for a Pipe of March’s Madeira Wine, to be imported by Mr Janney. Mrs Knight came with a Petition, for the discharge of her Son named Falconer, a Soldier who deserted nearly two years since, and is now she knows not where— So she says— Her petition affirms that in January 1825. the then Secretary of War promised her that her Son should be immediately discharged but that he was not. And that last Summer upon her renewal of her application, Coll. Jones the Adjutant General, in the absence of the Secretary of War told her that nothing could be done for her— Her petition was supported by the signatures of Genl. S. Smith and others. I told her I was apprehensive it would be impossible according to the established regulations of the army to grant a discharge for her son, while he was an avowed deserter; but that I would make the proper enquiries, and inform her to-morrow. I sent to ask General Brown to call upon me— His aid, Lieutenant Vinton came, and said he had been several days ill, and could not come out— I gave Lieutt. Vinton the petition of Mrs Knight, desiring him to shew it to Genl. Brown, and say to him I had sent for him to ask his opinion, upon the propriety of granting its prayer— Lieutt. Vinton soon afterwards returned, and said General Brown thought the discharge of Falconer could not be granted without injury to the service— Robert Lee who came with Walter Jones, is a Son of Charles Lee, some time Attorney General of the United States, and solicits admission as a Cadet at West-Point. He brought me Letters from his kinsmen Richard Bland Lee, and Edmund Jennings Lee—and says there is a vacancy at West-Point, from the Congressional District to which he belongs— I sent to ask Mr Forrest to call on me, and he came— I enquired if the order which W. S. Smith gave to R. Wallack, covered the whole debt for which Forrest had made himself liable, by endorsement— He said it did— He also said it had originated in a debt of Smith’s contracted at Pensacola— Mr Rush brought me the statements and documents from the Treasury to be used in the preparation of the Message— The falling off in the Revenue of the present year though amounting to near three Millions, in comparison with the last, will not be to the amount of one hundred thousand dollars, beyond the estimate of Mr Rush in his Report of last December— He read me a Letter he had written to his brother, intimating to him that a friend of the Collector, Steele would do him an act of kindness to let him know the reasons urging that he should resign, to relieve me from the otherwise necessary consideration of the question of his removal— He also read me an extract from a Letter of C. J. Ingersoll, informing him confidentially, that the Grand Jury, now in session, at the United States Circuit Court, would shortly indict Edward Thomson, Floyd S. Bailey, the two Nicholl’s, Mackay, and one or two others, for frauds against the revenue of the United States— Mr Clay called—he has prepared the draft of a reply to the offensive note of George Canning, and spoke with much confidence of the strength of the argument which would be with us in this controversy. He said he would send his draft this Evening to Mr Rush, to be forwarded to-morrow to Mr Southard, that I might have it on Friday; and that it might be considered in Cabinet Meeting on Saturday— Captain Reid once Commander of the Privateer General Armstrong, called to take leave, being upon his return to-morrow to New-York— He wishes to be appointed Surveyor of that Port, but said nothing of it to me— He told me he had been in the Navy
when my father was President— Degrand was here this Evening about three hours— Talking about the Direction of the Bank of the United States, and Pennsylvania Politics— I signed this morning a consent to a Deed of conveyance from James L. M’Donald a Choctaw Indian, to W. Trahern, of a Mile Square 27. May 1826. By 4. Article Treaty with Choctaws of 20. January 1825— And to a Deed from George Turnbull to Henry W. Vick 1. mile square— 21. June 1826.— And I signed a grant of Land of 1. Mile Square to Chubalk, a Chippewa Indian—by 3. Article of Treaty of Saginaw. 24. Septr. 1820.— I planted also in the garden 24. Black Oak, and 2. Post-Oak acorns 6 broad and 6 long Pennsylvania Walnuts—
9. V:30. Walk round the Capitol. Sun rose 6:59.

Mr Graham came to recommend the immediate appointment of a receiver of public monies at New-Orleans, and a person named Cox, being recommended by Mr Johnston the Senator from Louisiana. I signed a Commission to him— There were some others, the appointment of whom it was thought better to postpone, until the Meeting of Congress—as also the question respecting the removal of a Land Office in the State of Ohio to Tiffin, which seems to agitate and divide the whole State. Kennedy said he was from Middletown Connecticut and had married a Sister of Commodore Chauncey— Said also he had been on board the Deane Frigate in the Revolutionary War; but not long— Mr Wertz came again to solicit the delivery to him of his Commission as a Justice of Peace— I told him I had not yet made the enquiries I had intended concerning him, but would definitively decide in his case, if he would come again towards the close of next week— Mr Brent coming in soon afterwards I requested him to make the enquiries, what has been Wertz’s conduct, for some Months past, which he engaged to do. Mr Bulfinch came with sundry papers soliciting a loan, in behalf of the Unitarian Congregation, and with a hope that I would purchase the pew which I hire in their Church— I told him that being the only person of my family that attend the Church, I should not wish to encumber myself with the property of a pew— That as to a loan, my own Estate was now so much involved that I could dispose of nothing without an assurance of punctual payment; and that my experience of lending money to religious Societies was not encouraging— The Columbian College owed me a very large sum, of which they pay neither principal nor interest; and the Presbyterian Church of Mr Baker a small one; which they treat in the same manner— The compulsion of the Law cannot be applied to such Institutions, and they seem to consider the payment of their debts as not among the obligations of Christianity. I said however that recently the Columbian College had promised to make some provision for paying interest, which if they should carry into effect, I would assist the Unitarian Church by subscribing to their loan— I would therefore postpone giving him a definitive answer— Mrs. Knight came and I was constrained to tell her that her Son while a Deserter could not be discharged— It was an ungracious answer to give to a woman and a mother, but I could give no other— Captain Harrison of some revenue cutter, who has given me no small trouble before came with an appellate claim from the Treasury, for pay while he was here, settling his Accounts— I promised to look over his papers and give him an answer— Major Vandeventer brought me copies of the Powers from the late President and Secretary of War under which he received the annuities payable to the Seneca Indians— He brought me certificates of U.S. 6 per Cent Stocks, standing in the name of the President of the United States in trust for the Seneca Indians for more than 70,000 dollars, of loans now paid off and the interest upon which has ceased— Transfers were endorsed upon them to be signed by me, to receive payment of the principal, which then must be reinvested in stocks bearing an interest— I think the three per cents.
One of the certificates, was a renewed certificate, dated this day, yet made out in the name of James Madison President of the United States; which at my desire was altered, to the President of the United States for the time being— Vandeventer says that these Stocks were to secure to the Seneca Indians an annuity of six thousand dollars a year— But the practice has been to deposit the dividends of Interest in Bank to the credit of the Treasurer of the United States, and to pay the annuity to the Indians from the appropriations of the year. Mr Clay mentioned to me various subjects, in the current business of the Department; among the rest, the Settlements of the late R. C. Anderson’s accounts: and the question whether the outfit should be allowed, he having died on his way to the place of meeting— I had no doubt it should, and thought the funeral expenses also should be allowed: but desired him to refer to the vouchers in the Department to ascertain, if they were allowed on the Settlement of Mr Rodney’s accounts— Dr Lane came with a claim of 32000 dollars assigned to him by a man named Hanes once Marshal of Alabama, for maintaining two years, the Slaves of the infamous Constitution, Louisa and Merino importation— I postponed my decision upon the claim, to examine the papers which were sent me this Evening from the Navy Department— Degrand was here again this Evening; and took leave, intending to depart to-morrow Morning on his return to Philadelphia— He had seen Mr Rush, and communicated to him his desire to be a Director of the Bank of the United States— I was up writing till near Midnight.
10. VI:15— Round Capitol Square in one hour— Sun rose at 7: while I was out.

I made a race round the Capitol Square by way of experiment to ascertain in how short a time I could perform it and was exactly one hour by the Clock on my Mantle piece. Dr Lane came for my decision upon his claim; it appeared by the Report of the Secretary of the Navy, that the Negroes for the maintenance of whom he claimed, at the rate of 40 cents a day per head, for two years were actually not in his custody one month—many of them not ten days— Mr Southard had made out an account for the actual time amounting to 420 dollars— I told Lane, I doubted whether I should direct the payment even of that— I said that the presentation of such a claim, was a transaction, the character of which I knew of no honest word to designate— The Court had decreed that the Negroes should be placed in the custody of three persons, authorised to employ them in work to pay for their cloathing and subsistence, and upon condition that they should cause no expence to any person— They were so delivered: received and kept upon that condition; and this man charges 32000 dollars for keeping them two years, that is as long as he had the office of Marshal not having had them in his charge after the order of the Court a single day— He said that Armstrong, the present Marshal had been paid by my express direction, for the same charge, after he came into office; and that the Marshals of Georgia and Mississippi had been paid, for keeping the same negroes. The payment of Armstrong’s charge was by my order upon a Report of the Secretary of the Navy— But Armstrong had them actually in his charge; by an order of the Court, which authorised him to employ them at moderate work to pay for their maintenance: Armstrong was allowed something additional, which the order of Court did not prohibit; though if I had known of this order of the Court, I should not have sanctioned the additional payment: That to Morel the Marshal of Georgia was made by direction of Mr Monroe, much to my dissatisfaction, though it being business of the Navy department, I took little part in the affair— Of the payment to the Marshal of Mississippi I knew nothing. Mr Baker the Clergyman came with a petition of two persons to be discharged from prison, to which they have been some months confined for an assault and Battery— I told Mr Baker it must have the signature or recommendation of one of the Judges, or of the District Attorney; to obtain which he took it away. Mr Reed came with Mr Kinsman of Philadelphia, and Dr Dudley of Virginia— Reed said he was the
person who some time since had made an experiment in this house of an improved steam-machine: the others professedly came only upon a friendly visit. Mr Kinsman spoke of my having heard Mr Bedell, an episcopal clergyman, preach here, and at Philadelphia— Major Vandeventer brought me the Powers; and I desired him to write to Mr Biddle, President of the U.S. Bank, to ascertain on what terms a purchase of U.S. 3. per Cent Stocks may be made— Mr Johnston, the Senator from Louisiana, came and left with me a Letter, soliciting my interference for the institution of a tribunal to try the validity of Land-titles in the purchased territories— He had sent me a Letter from Mr Thomas H. Benton the Senator from Missouri, to him and Mr Bouligny the other Louisiana Senator, enclosing a Memorial to me, from certain persons in Missouri, claiming my recommendation to Congress of measures for confirming Land-grants, which they complain they have not been able to obtain— Mr Benton asks the aid of the Louisiana Senators to the Memorial. Mr Benton’s movement is one of his electioneering engines for securing his own re-election as a Senator— He has also another motive in it, well suited to his character, which is more of the Cethegus Class than any other man I know in this Country— Mr Rush read me a Letter he had received from Georgia, concerning the culture of the Silkworm, and proposing bounties upon the manufacture of sewing Silk. I asked him to direct some further Statements to be sent me from the Treasury, for the preparation of the Message; and suggested for his consideration, the expediency of recommending again to Congress a loan of ten or fifteen Millions at 4 1/2 per Cent or 5. redeemable in 1829 or 1830—with which so much of the six per Cents now or at the end of this year becoming redeemable might be paid off— It would save one per Cent a year or more upon the whole of the amount of the loan— Mr Rush hesitated upon this measure, because it had been recommended last Winter and was not adopted by Congress— But it was then very doubtful whether the loan would succeed; there is now every probability that it would. If it had then been authorised it would have saved 90000 dollars to the public even this year; and if it should fail again the responsibility would rest not upon us but upon Congress— We discussed the subject till Mr Rush considered it more favourably, and he will write to the President of the Bank to ascertain if they would not undertake the whole or a part of the Loan— W. Lee came to ask permission to go for a week or ten days to Philadelphia, to advise Commodore Stewart, and his wife about their separation— She has written to me to request my interposition— I desired Mr Lee to tell her that wishing to render her any service in my power, it would be impossible for me to take any step in it without first knowing that it was equally the desire of Commodore Stewart as her own— That she had further annexed a condition of listening to no accommodation which would separate her from her children, which would of itself render all agency of mine ineffectual. Lee said that the Children were a daughter about eleven years old, and a son, about seven— That the Commodore offered to let her take the girl, but insisted upon having the boy himself— This I thought altogether reasonable, observing that by Law, he had the right to take them both, and that he ought to take the boy to place him in a way to receive a good education— Lee requested me also to decide upon the case of Lieutenant Alberti— Mr Southard called early in the Evening, and brought me Mr Clay’s draft of an Instruction to Mr Gallatin in reply to the Note of George Canning on the British interdiction of our shipping in their Colonial Ports— In reading this, and the defence of Lieutenant Alberti, and other papers relating to his trial I was occupied till past eleven, and then in writing a Remission of the unexecuted part of the Sentence of the Court Martial, and of the suspension of his pay and emoluments, midnight approached before I retired to bed. I wrote nothing upon the draft of my Message, and the journal of yesterday remains incomplete.
11. VI:5— Walk to the Theatre— Sun rose at 7:1—

Mr Southard brought me the papers relating to the trial of Lieutenant C. Smith—and made some remarks upon my draft of a decision, which he thought right on the whole, but doubtful as to part of the reasoning. He thought it countenanced the idea, that Coll. Henderson’s conditional forbearance to prosecute Smith for his misconduct at the Navy Yard here last December was equivalent to a pardon— I had stated that the right of the Commander of the Marine Corps to convene a general Court Martial was now undoubted— There was among the papers a copy of a Letter from Robert Smith when Secretary of State, in answer to an enquiry from Coll. Wharton, then Commander of the Corps, which said that he had the exclusive right to convene such Courts; but Mr Southard pointed to the argument of Captain Randall, Smith’s Counsel, that the Commander of the Marine Corps, having only the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, could not convene a general Court-Martial, the 65th. Article of War giving the power only to any general officer commanding an army or Colonel commanding a separate Department—but I thought the term Colonel in the Article, as it does in common parlance, included Lieutenant Colonels, in which construction Mr Southard concurred with me. Finally Mr Southard took my draft as it was to the Department, and sent me a copy of it which I signed. Mr Brent came to enquire for a Letter from General P. B. Porter, which I had already sent back to the Department. Dobbin was a young man from Baltimore, and Meeteer from Bucks County, Pennsylvania who visited me merely from curiosity. Captain Harrison came for a decision in his case, which from a claim for pay while he was dismissed from the service, has changed to the demand of a per diem allowance while he was here, settling his Accounts— I told him I should refer this to the Secretary of the Treasury and accordingly gave the papers to Mr Rush to decide upon them— He had already rejected the claim for pay— A Cabinet Meeting attended by Messrs.Clay, Rush and Southard, considered the draft of a Letter of Instruction to Mr Gallatin, prepared by Mr Clay, upon the British interdiction of our shipping in their West-India Colonies— It is a thorough refutation of the false pretences, and a keen retort upon the sarcastic insolence of Canning’s Note. There was not much discussion of it, and it was not read— There were in one or two passages concessions of a right in Great Britain to ordain this interdiction, and to refuse negotiation concerning it— I thought they had better be omitted, the right of interdicting commerce being questionable when applied exclusively to one Nation, and that of refusing Negotiation, scarcely being maintainable after a formal and positive promise to negotiate— I thought also there should be some enlargement of remark, upon the discrimination made in British Acts of Parliament in their conditions upon the admission of shipping, between Nations having Colonies and Nations having none— The latter designation applying in its practical operation almost exclusively to the United States, and being only a covert mode of establishing regulations, peculiarly adverse to them— There was question whether a Proclamation of retaliatory interdict of British shipping from the Colonies should not be issued under the act of Congress of 1. March 1823. but as this measure cannot with propriety be taken, until we know that the British interdict has taken effect, and it commences only from the first of December, we thought it best to refer the whole subject to Congress— Mr Clay’s note said among other things, that it would not be proper to communicate to the British Government the purport of Mr Gallatin’s instructions relating to the colonial trade— Yet he proposed that they should be sent to Congress with the Message— I asked whether this would not appear inconsistent. He said the question had occurred to himself— But he thought a direct communication of them to the British Government, would seem like an entreaty to them to resume the Negotiation though they have declared they will not negotiate— But with the Message to Congress, it will go only as information to our own
Countrymen, and if the British Government obtain it thus indirectly, it will be without impropriety, or debasement on our part— There were some nettles scattered through the Note which Mr Clay pointed out for consideration— I said I wished them all to remain; for after flooring Mr Canning upon his Logic, it was well to give him also some return for his gibes— After this object of the meeting was gone through, mention was made by Mr Rush, of my proposal for recommending to Congress again a loan at 4 1/2 or 5 per Cent, redeemable in 1829 and 1830. to redeem the six per Cent Stocks now or immediately becoming redeemable— Mr Clay thought that the name of a loan would be liable to a misrepresentation, as if it was to increase instead of diminishing the debt; but such a misrepresentation would be so easily refuted that it ought not to stand in the way of a measure of real economy— Mr Rush will pursue the subject farther. Lieutenant Alberti called here this evening to urge an immediate decision in his case, as he was desirous of leaving the City on Monday— I told him I had the decision already prepared, and mentioned what it was— I said if he would call on Major Vandeventer and ask him to come to me this Evening or to-morrow Morning I would give him the remission and the Papers, so that he, Alberti need not be detained in the City over Monday— I also told him that it had not been my intention to reverse the decision upon the Sentence of the Court Martial, by General Scott, but merely to remit the unexecuted part of the penalty— Johnson Hellen and my Son John went this morning to Rockville— John returned this evening— I wrote again till near Midnight.
12. VI:30. Walk round House Square. 18 Minutes— Sun rose 7:2. Sunday.

Major Vandeventer called this morning for the papers and remission of penalty, in the case of Lieutt. Alberti, which I gave him— He said he would bring me to-morrow the Reports and Statements from the War Department, necessary for the preparation of the Message— General Scott had remitted one Month of the Suspension from Rank, pay and emoluments which the Court-Martial had fixed for twelve months from the 10th. of last February the date of their Sentence— He had offered to remit further the suspension from the first of this month— Lieutenant Alberti, appealed both from the Sentence of the Court-Martial, and from the decision of General Scott, to the War Department and it thus came to me. Without reversing either the Sentence of the Court, or the decision of General Scott, I remitted the remainder of the suspension from rank, and the whole suspension of pay and emoluments— The prosecution was malicious. I heard Mr Little this morning, from Luke 7:16. “And there came a fear on all: and they glorified God, saying, that a great prophet is risen up among us; and that God hath visited his people.” It was something between a Discourse, and a Speech in defence of the Miracles, recorded in the Scriptures: partly read from his Notes, and partly extemporaneous commentary— But this is not the manner in which that subject ought to be treated— The miracles of the New Testament appear to have been performed, as evidences of the divine Mission of Christ— Faith was to be founded on the mighty works by which it was authenticated: but now the order of proof is reversed— It is the doctrine of the Scriptures alone that can obtain credence for the miracles— Mr Little read several extracts from a Dudleian Lecture of Mr Channing’s upon this subject, with great commendation— They were very ingenious and eloquent, but the drift of them was to prove that there is no reason for disbelieving the scriptural accounts of Miracles, or that the Creator should bind himself to exclusive operation by general Laws— This is very true, but it does not meet the question; which is not upon the power of the creator, but upon the fact of the miracle— The miracles in the Bible, furnish the most powerful of all the objections, against its authenticity, both historical and doctrinal—and were it possible to take its sublime morals, its unparalleled conceptions of the nature of God and its irresistible power over the heart, with the simple narrative of the life and death of Jesus, strip’d of all the supernatural agency, and all the marvellous incidents connected with it, I should receive it without any of those misgivings of unwilling incredulity as to the miracles which I find
it impossible altogether to cast off. Mr Little had not respect enough for his text; after the service I called to see Governor Barbour who is slowly convalescent from his fever. Much better than last Sunday, but still feeble— He said he had rode this morning four or five miles on horseback— He had on his table the Newspapers of the Northern Mail; with some returns of the recent Election in New-York, which he thought unfavourable— He also read me an extract of a Letter from Governor Pleasants of Virginia— I saw Mrs Barbour and her Daughter— In the afternoon I heard Mr at Mr Baker’s—from Matthew 21.33–46. but chiefly 44. “And whosoever shall fall on this stone shall be broken: but on whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him to powder.” Sentence of Reprobation, never pretermitted— Evening passed in writing.
13. VI:15— To Capitol Hill Bridges— 40 minutes. Sun rose 7:3.

Mr Hamilton came to solicit a Clerkship in one of the Departments, and brought me a Letter of recommendation from Ludwell Lee— Myers and Wilson are two inhabitants of Washington, who say they have purchased lots of Captain John Davidson, and have built upon them; but Davidson had not paid for them; and now the Commissioner of the Public Buildings insists that they must pay interest upon Davidson’s purchase money, from the day when he bought them till this time. They think it hard and say the Commissioner of Public Buildings tells them I have the power to remit this interest— I told them I thought they had misunderstood Mr Elgar, but that I would see him, and should be glad to do for them any thing that I could with propriety— General Brown who had been some days quite unwell, paid me a visit on his recovery— He left with me the Albany Daily Advertiser, containing two Essays of his writing, which had been published in the National Journal, 5 and 6. October, and which he had sent to Governor Clinton, requesting him to cause them to be reprinted there— There were a defence of the Administration for a certain distribution of the army which has given some dissatisfaction in the territory of Michigan, and the Western part of New-York. The General referred also to the recent Elections in New-York; where Mr Rochester, has been set up as a Candidate for Governor against De Witt Clinton— He was probably set up for the purpose of being beaten, and then for representing him as an Administration Candidate, and his defeat as a defeat of the Administration— It was notoriously impossible that he should succeed against Clinton; and it looked more like a burlesque upon competition, than like a serious adverse Candidate. General Brown thought it would be imputed to Mr Clay, though he said he himself did not believe it. He speculated much as usual upon New-York politics, and always as a friend to Clinton— Mr Clay came at one with Mr Stein Bille, Chargé d’Affaires from Denmark; who told me he was brother to the Commander of the Gun-boats whom I had seen at Fleckeroï in Norway in September 1809— This Gentleman speaks English with much facility, and is a man of lively and pleasant Conversation— Mr Clay afterwards returned and spoke of his Letter of Instructions to Mr Gallatin, which he said he proposed sending to-morrow— Coll. Jones the Adjutant General brought me a Letter from General Scott to Genl. Brown, transmitting to him the proceedings of the Court Martial, upon the trial of Lieutt. Harrison, and expressing his surprize that the Court should have recommended his restoration to the Service; he being in General Scott’s opinion altogether unworthy of it— Coll. Jones said he had not thought it proper to transmit this ex parte paper to me with the papers; but he had thought it should be communicated to me before the promulgation of my decision— I told him I did not know what might have been its effect on my determination, had I seen the paper before I had made the decision, but that it was now too late for any alteration— I thought some part of the testimony against Harrison had been disproved, but I had restored him reluctantly, and only at the recommendation
of the Court— Mr Parmly presented himself as a dentist, and I took the opportunity to have a decayed tooth drawn— He also scaled off the Tartar which has been for years collecting upon my lower front teeth, and urged the drawing of another—the consideration of which I postponed till to-morrow. Mr Southard came to enquire if he should give a Midshipman’s warrant to a young man named Heyward, from Maine, a disqualified Cadet, but with testimonials of good conduct, like Forsyth. I consented that he should have a Warrant— He asked also what he should be done with John and Joshua Boyd— I told him that I understood John was now with his father, and wished to have an additional furlough for six Months more, that which he now has being for six Months, to prepare himself for examination— Mrs Adams had told me, that Joshua might be dismissed from the Service; but as I have never done that with any Officer, I was unwilling to begin with him— I therefore desired Mr Southard, to order him to report himself for duty to Commodore Chauncey at the Navy-Yard, New-York with notice that upon the first act of disobedience of which he should be guilty, he would be dismissed from the service. Mr Southard spoke of the recent Election of U.S. Senator, by the New Jersey Legislature, in which Ephraim Bateman was elected, openly voting for himself—the votes without him being 28 and 28. Southard said it had occasioned great exasperation and bitterness between the parties, which he feared would be still increased by the appointment of W. Rossell, as U.S District Judge— It is a revival of the old contest between the federal and democratic parties— I was occupied from 7 to 11 in the Evening in writing—
14. V:15. Round Capitol Square 1 hour 2 minutes— Sun rose 7:4.

Major Nourse brought and read to me a short summary of a plan for a uniform organization of the Militia: which I understood him would be reported by the Board of Officers now assembled here to advise with the Secretary of War— The principal feature of the plan is a division of all the Militia-men into two Classes—one from 21. to 25. and the other from 25 to 45— Mr Frye called to mention, that the Bill of W. S. Smith, endorsed by him, which was protested last Summer, and is in the Navy Department must be paid this day, and that he had not money to pay it—and he said he thought it was one of those which if not paid, would be reported to Congress— I gave Mr Frye, a check upon the Bank, for the whole of W. S. Smith’s order in his favour including this Navy Department Bill: and took a receipt from him, for the Executors— Mr Southard came as he said to ask my advice. Some time since a man named Spafford was recommended by Mr Berrien the Senator, and Coll. Tattnall a member of the House of Representatives from Georgia, for an appointment as Purser in the Navy; and Mr Southard had given him some expectation of success— But Captain . . . mentioned to Southard some equivocal and discreditable conduct at Boston, and a few days after Spafford, brought to Southard an anonymous Letter, purporting to be to Spafford; warning him that he had an enemy at the Department, and the writer pretending to have overheard at the Navy Department a conversation, against him— Mr Southard, upon the first inspection of the Letter thought from the similarity of hand writing between the Letter and Spafford’s application for an appointment that the Letter was written by Spafford himself— He informed him of this Suspicion,
and Spafford produced a declaration from a man in Savannah named Deft, that he wrote the application for Spafford’s appointment as Purser, and did not write the anonymous Letter— But now Mr Berrien writes a Letter to Mr Southard, referring to these imputations upon his protegé, and enquiring whether they were the only cause of the appointments being withheld from him— Southard had written a draft of an answer to Berrien, which I thought more argumentative and apologetic than was necessary— I advised him to answer that from similarity of hand-writing he had entertained suspicion that Mr Spafford wrote the anonymous Letter himself. That Spafford had satisfied him that this suspicion was unfounded— That Mr Spafford had told him he knew the author of the anonymous Letter, and promised to inform him who it was; which he still might do—and that it was not the only cause of his not recommending Spafford for the appointment— Southard said he still suspected the Letter was written by Spafford, or with his knowledge— Mr Clay brought me a Letter from the President of the Republic of Central America, announcing the recall of Mr Cañaz their Minister Plenipotentiary, and informed me that the Chargé d’Affaires recently arrived wished to be introduced to me, and I appointed to-morrow at one O’Clock to receive him.— Mr Clay read to me also the additional paragraphs he had written for the Instruction to Mr Gallatin, on the British Colonial Interdict— Major Vandeventer came with a brief statement of the estimates from the War Department, for 1827. compared with those of 1826. But the Reports from the various branches of the Department are not yet ready— Mr Parmly came and completed his operations upon my teeth— He declined taking pay, but asked me for a recommendation. He is going soon to Charleston S.C. and will call again tomorrow— In this and the three preceding days, I have signed 681. Land-grants and 6. Virginia Military Land-warrants— Evening drowsy.
15. V: Round Capitol Square. 1. hour 2 minutes. Sun rose in Hazy Cloud—invisible.

Mr Hanlon came for a subscription to a Roman Catholic female School in Washington County, Kentuckey— Captain Harrison, for a decision upon his claim for a per diem compensation, during the time that he was in attendance for the settlement of his accounts at the Treasury. Mr Parmly came to introduce his brother, gave me a box of dentifrice and took leave; going in the Steamboat to Norfolk, on his way to Charleston S.C— Mr M’Kenney came with a Letter from Mr Nevins the Clergyman at Baltimore requesting him to obtain an interview, with me for his brother Samuel Nevins of Philadelphia—to which I assented. Mr M’Kenney gave me two small Stones which he said he had picked up on the shores of Lake Superior, on his excursion there last Summer: one of them a Cornaline, about the size of a pea, which he had had polished at New-York, and which he desired me to present to Mrs Adams; and the other which he thought an Agate, in the natural Estate, which he gave me. Mr Heman Lincoln of Boston, brought me Letters of introduction from Mr Webster and Mr Quincy— Mr Nevins, a brother and partner in business with the broker of the same name, solicits again the restoration to them of 51000 dollars worth of Edward Thomson’s Teas, about which there has already been so much negotiation— He complained that there had been some inconsistent conduct towards them of the District Attorney at Philadelphia. and wished to obtain the teas for which they had the inward bills of lading, without engaging that the proceeds should be paid in to the Bank of the United States, as the New-York Insurance Companies, and F. H. Nicoll have done— He said that Thomson and the other persons recently indicted by the Grand-Jury at Philadelphia, had conspired to defraud them, the Nevins’s, which is probable. I
I referred him for the settlement of business to the Secretary of the Treasury. Wyer arrived this morning from St. Petersburg, where he went as a special Messenger with despatches to Mr Middleton— He arrived last Saturday at Boston, after a stormy passage of 80 days from Cronstadt. He brought me Letters from Mr Middleton, from Mr Gibson the Consul, and from J. D. Lewis— He dined with us— Mr Clay came and introduced to me the new Chargé d’Affaires from Guatemala Don Pedro Gonzales: a very young man— The late Minister Plenipotentiary Mr Cañaz, and his Secretary of Legation Mr Valero having returned to their Country. Mr Clay afterwards returned, and read me a note to Mr Vaughan the British Minister, in answer to the proposal of the British Government concerning the Boundary Line Commission under the Treaty of Ghent— Also the Notes which have passed between him and the Danish Chargé d’Affaires Bille, concerning the Construction of Article in the recently concluded Convention, which he proposed to publish— Mr Rush was here, and brought me voluminous papers to read— Among the rest those relating to a claim of Joseph Otis, sometime Collector of Barnstable— We had also further conversation relating to the renewed application of the Nevins’s. I thought it might be advisable to state to them, that the Teas for which they had the bill of lading might be delivered to them, on their giving ample security for payment of the proceeds to the United States in the event of the decision of the Court’s being in their favour— We had further conversation upon the question whether a loan for reducing the interest upon ten or sixteen Millions of the public debt from 6 to 5 per Cent should be proposed to Congress, upon which he still hesitates— He brought me a more detailed Statement of the public expenditures in the years 1824–5. and 6. Wyer spent part of the Evening with me, and that disappointed me for writing afterwards— I had passed all the leisure of the day in reading the trial of another drunkard Lieutenant in the Army, named Phineas Andrews.
16. V. Round Capitol Square— 1. hour 5 minutes— Sun rose in hazy Cloud—invisible.

Mrs Royall, has published a Book, of Travels in the interior of the Country— She came to me two or three years since for a subscription, and other things— Her Book has since that time been published, in which she indulges herself in sarcastic remarks upon many individuals— She says that it takes wonderfully, and that she has a very great subscription. Mr Lincoln and Dr Bowles called upon me, but Mr Rush coming in immediately afterwards they postponed opening their business until to-morrow, when they are to dine with me— Mr Rush consulted me with regard to the reply to his brother, the Doctor, in relation to the Collector of the Port of Philadelphia— From Dr. Rush’s answer to his brother it would seem that Mr Steele inclines to resign; but wishes to know how far in that Event, he will be sustained by the Government, in the actions at Law which have been commenced against him in his official capacity— I thought it would be best to say that the Government could give no pledge on that subject; but that no doubt the Governmt would sustain him, as far after his resignation, as they could while he should remain in Office— He gave me also a long communication from a Mr Gobert at St. Augustine, on the cultivation of Silk— Mr Clay, brought a despatch received from Mr Gallatin, enclosing his answer to the note of G. Canning of the 11th. of September, last— Clay said he was very glad that a reply to that note had been already sent from hence, as he thought Mr Gallatin’s note had not made a case near so strong in our favour, as his paper had— On reading Mr Gallatin’s note, I thought there was in it, too much of concession,
and not quite enough of retort— The despatches from Mr Middleton, brought by E. Wyer, had been sent to me early this Morning— The Emperor Nicholas had postponed until he should be at Moscow, the private Audience to receive his Credential Letter; but Count Nesselrode, the Minister of Foreign Affairs had informed Mr Middleton, that he might for the transaction of business consider himself as already fully accredited. Mr Middleton had received the invitation to the foreign Ambassadors and Ministers to attend the Coronation, and with Mr C Pinkney had departed for Moscow the day before Wyer embarked— Mr Clay mentioned to me his wish to make an excursion, perhaps as far as New-York, for eight or ten days; for relaxation from the labours of his Office— He proposes to go the day after to-morrow, and to return a few days before the Meeting of Congress— He said he had business; and Mr Johnston, the Senator from Louisiana, would probably go with him— He added that he should avoid crowds; and that he had a Son, on probation at West-Point. I read to him that portion of the Draft of the Message, which concerns our foreign Relations, upon which he made some remarks— He said that Governor Barbour had intimated to him a wish that the Draft of the Message, when prepared might be sent to the Members of the Administration, to be considered by them without my being present.— That the discussion might be more free than would be respectful in my presence— I said I saw no material objection to this— I finished reading the proceedings of the Court-Martial on the trial of first Lieutenant Phineas Andrews, 5th. Regiment of Infantry; upwards of 200 manuscript pages—and I approved the Sentence of the Court, dismissing him from the Army— I approved also ten Leases of Lead mines N. 52–61 by Lieutenant Thomas, in Missouri.
17. VI— Rain— No Morning walk.— Round the House Square before dinner— Company to dine 3.

Major Vandeventer brought me part of the Reports from the various branches of the War Department, necessary for the preparation of the Message; but the most important of them all, that from the Engineer Department is not yet ready— A Letter from T. L. M’Kenney of the Indian Department to G. Graham, Commissioner of the General Land-Office, asking that the proceeds of Sales of 54. Sections of Land, for the benefit of Choctaw Schools, by 8 Article of Treaty of 1820—should be passed to the Credit of the Indian Department, with Mr Graham’s answer, and a statement of the sums realized, had been sent me this Morning— I desired Major Vandeventer to say to Mr M’Kenney that I should be glad to see him— I asked him also to send a similar message to Lieutenant Phillips, from whom I had a few days since received a Letter, complaining of grievances from a Court martial, and requesting to see me— He soon came and bitterly complained of having been ordered upon duties, which in his habitual ill health, he could not perform— He brought me several Letters from respectable persons testifying to the respectability of his character; but he did not state to me, what was the sentence of the Court Martial, which he considered as a grievance— Nor had I seen it— He said it was now before General Brown, for revision— The General himself came in while Phillips was with me— The Lieutenant called on me again, and I promised when I should see the papers of his case, to consider of what he said— General Brown was in great consternation at the news of the Election in New-York, where Mr Clinton is rechosen Governor, but by a majority of not more hundreds than he had of thousands, at the last Election two years since— It is somewhat amazing to me, that a man, having no more hold upon life than he, should take such deep interest in mere election incidents— He said that the State of New-York, was in the hands of Martin Van Buren; that
he would certainly be re-elected to the U.S. Senate— That Mr Clinton would be at his mercy, and he did not know what the consequence would be— Mr M’Kenney came with a Letter from Mr Thomas Mann Randolph Senr. in answer to one from Govr. Barbour, offering him an appointment as Commissioner of U.S. for running the boundary line between Georgia and Florida— He postpones his acceptance of the appointment to ask sundry questions—and for Instructions— I said it would be sufficient to give him general Instructions, leaving all the details, to be concerted with the Commissioner of the State of Georgia, at his discretion— As the act of Congress authorises also the appointment of a Surveyor, I desired Mr M’Kenney to enquire of Governor Barbour, if he had fixed upon any person to recommend— I spoke also of the Choctaw School funds, and requested Mr M’Kenney to send me the papers from the Department which would shew what had been already done upon the subject— He spoke of the School which has been established in Kentuckey, by their own determination, and which will require the application of the Capital of the fund— The papers were afterwards sent to me— H. Lee came to ask me to return some manuscript Letters of General Washington, which he had lent me I believe a year ago— I could not immediately recollect where they were, but promised to look them up and return them soon. I returned to him another bundle of Letters which the Postmaster General had given me, concerning Lee himself. Lee’s reputation is bad with regard to private morals, and his political course is unprincipled—but he writes with great force and elegance, and Mr Calhoun has used him for that purpose— Through Calhoun’s influence the Postmaster General gave Lee some small office in that Department, where it is said he has used the advantages of the situation, against the Administration, and to promote the purposes of his patron: while he has at the same time been constantly writing abusive pieces, for the Newspaper called the Telegraph, the Phoenix from the ashes of the Washington City Gazette— In the first half year, after I came into Office, I received a number of anonymous Letters, apparently from various quarters of the Union, but I believe all written in this City, charging Lee with these things, and the Postmaster General, with being accessory to them— I spoke of them two or three times to Mr M’lean, who declared them calumnious as respected himself, and that he believed them so, as regarded Mr Lee— He also sent me these Letters as recommendatory of Lee, among which was one from Mr Jefferson, curious, as containing some interesting remarks on the Declaration of Independence— Lee now told me that he had withdrawn from that place in the Post-Office, which he had only taken because he had been solicited to accept it— That he should offer himself as a Candidate for Congress, in Virginia and that he regretted I had been troubled on account of the place he had held in the Post-Office— He also recommended a son of one of his friends in Virginia, for a Midshipman’s warrant, and asked me to give him my signature in writing, and if I had them to spare, one of my fathers and of Mr Monroes, which he wanted to send to a British Officer whom he had lately met in Quebec, and who wished to obtain and preserve them as curiosities— Mr Clay called, and took leave, proposing to go to-morrow for New York. He does not view the Election in the State of New-York, in the same light with General Brown; but the fact is that Governor Clinton has been re-elected by a small majority; but that there will be in both houses of the Legislature majorities against him. Mr Clay said he should probably stay not more than one day in New-York— Coll. Trumbull called, and he, and Dr. Bowles and Mr Lincoln dined with us— Coll. Trumbull is here to direct the disposition of his four Pictures in the Circular room at the Capitol— He mentioned to me again, as he had at New-York on my last passage there his wish, after the Pictures shall be placed, to give them a finishing revision; but he now thinks he shall be obliged to wait for that purpose until the ensuing Spring— Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen were both unwell, and did not dine with us— My guests retired so early this evening, that I was enabled afterwards a part of the days Journal, and a short Letter to my Son George— I signed the Exequatur’s to several Vice-Consuls, and the Credential Full Power to J. Sergeant.
18. V:30. Round Capitol Square. Sun rose in Clouds.

Mr Williams is brother in Law to General Brown, who introduced him, and lives in the Western part of the State of New-York. He told me he was a member of the House of Representatives in Congress from that State when I was in the Senate. Mr Wertz came again for his Commission as a Justice of the Peace— I told him that if he would call at the Department of State, and ask them to make out and send me a Commission for him I would sign it— He expressed much gratitude for this and assured me, that I should never have occasion from any misconduct of his to regret my determination in his favour. Mr Brent afterwards came over, and I desired him to have the commission made out. Mr Palacio who has been residing at Philadelphia, as Consul General of the Republic of Colombia, came with Mr Brent to take leave, being about to embark at New-York for Rio de Janeiro, where he goes with an appointment of Minister Plenipotentiary to the Government of Brazil. He appears to be and is in bad health, and said this Climate was too cold for his Constitution. Dr Wallace was here, as voluble and scientific in his conversation as ever— He said he was just recovering from a dropsy. He discoursed upon entomology—the wonderful transformations of insects, and the voracious properties of the dragon-fly, and lion-ant, or formicales, the same animal under different forms— He spoke of its aquatic terrestrial, and aerial successive states of existence, as illustrative of the condition of man; and he repeated what he had said to me before, that my fresh water baths in the Summer, were injurious to my health; affecting as he said the liver— He attempted some demonstration about the absorption of vital air in the water upon the viscera, which I neither understood nor believed; but he admitted that bathing in Salt-water was wholesome, because he said there was more oxygen in Sea than in river water— His conversation is entertaining, ingenious and learned, but abounding in fanciful theory, and over confident in matters upon which the only safe process of the mind would be doubt— Mr Southard came, and asked my opinion of a second Letter which he had received from Mr Berrien the Georgia Senator concerning the anonymous Letter to Spafford— With it Mr Berrien, had enclosed a Letter from Tennison the tavern keeper and his son, and a certificate from a Major Denney, from which it appears that the anonymous Letter, had been concerted between them and another, dictated by Tennison the father, and written by the Son— But the reason for writing it, is very lamely accounted for, the artifice of sending it to Alexandria, that it might come Post-marked from that place, the mystery of describing it under the denomination of another, the fourth associate in the stratagem, and the acknowledgment of eaves-dropping at Navy-Department, are all circumstances little adapted to remove suspicions that Spafford had some agency in the transaction, being at the time, a boarder at Tennison’s house— Mr Berrien professes now to have no other interest in this matter, than to justify his own recommendation of Spafford. I advised Mr Southard to see Mr Berrien, and to explain to him in conversation the grounds of suspicion still existing, but with full assurances that not the remotest idea was entertained, that he had knowledge of any thing unfavourable to the character of Spafford, when he recommended him— I mentioned to Mr Southard H. Lee’s recommendation of a youth named Brown, for a Midshipman’s Warrant— He said that he had been obliged to withstand Mr Taliaferro’s solicitations for the same person; and that now if he should yield to Lee’s application, Lee would abuse the favour in two ways—first by making a handle of it to detach the boy’s father from the Administration, to which he is now friendly; and secondly to boast of it as a proof that he had influence to obtain here, that which had been denied to Mr Taliaferro. I told Southard that Lee had informed me he should offer himself as a Candidate for Congress— Southard said he was glad of it, for it would be against Taliaferro, and would tend to ensure his election. He said that Lee was under such obligations to Taliaferro that he was the last man in the world whom he ought to oppose; but he thought Lee’s profligacy at least equal to his talents— My Son John went this morning to Rockville, and returned late in the Evening with Johnson Hellen.
19. VII:15. Sun risen Clear— Sunday—

Heard Mr Little this morning from Haggai. 1.7. “Thus saith the Lord of Hosts; Consider your ways.” He gave an historical account of this prophet, and of the occasion upon which his prophecy was written— To urge the building of the second Temple—and he attributed to State policy the motives of the Medo-Persian Empire, for shewing favour to the Jews; supposing it to have been occasioned by jealousy of the rising power of the Grecian Republics. But the principal part of the discourse consisted in the application of the prophetical admonition to our own times and to the auditory of the preacher— After the morning service I had a visit from Mr Peter Hagner, the third Auditor. He has just returned from his journey to North-Carolina, Raleigh, where he went to attend the trial of a man, who had attempted to pass a forgery upon him, by the name of Reed to procure the payment of a Pension to a widow woman— But before the trial was to come on, and before Mr Hagner reached Raleigh the man had died in prison— In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker, from Psalm 149.2.— “Let the children of Zion, be joyful in their King,” a text not altogether congenial to the Calvinistic creed; or to the topics usually pressed by preachers of the Presbyterian Church— It was upon the enjoyments of religion— In the Evening I resumed the draft of the annual message, and the reading of papers from the Departments preparatory for it— My papers for reading accumulate.
20. VI. Round Capitol Square in one hour— Sun rose 7:10
